title: SM UC-7
text:
SM "UC-7" was a German <a href="German%20Type%20UC%20I%20submarine">Type UC I</a> <a href="minelayer">minelayer</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a> or <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> in the <a href="German%20Imperial%20Navy">German Imperial Navy</a> () during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. The U-boat had been ordered by November 1914 and was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launch</a>ed on 6 July 1915. She was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commission</a>ed into the German Imperial Navy on 9 July 1915 as SM "UC-7". <a href="Naval%20mines">Mines</a> laid by "UC-7" in her 34 patrols were credited with sinking 32 ships.
Design.
A <a href="German%20Type%20UC%20I%20submarine">German Type UC I submarine</a>, "UC-7" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a <a href="length%20overall">length overall</a> of , a <a href="beam%20%28ship%29">beam</a> of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by one <a href="Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft">Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft</a> six-cylinder, four-stroke diesel engine producing , an electric motor producing , and one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. She was capable of operating at a depth of .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, she could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "UC-7" was fitted with six mine tubes, twelve UC 120 mines, and one machine gun. She was built by <a href="AG%20Vulcan%20Stettin">AG Vulcan Stettin</a> and her <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> was fourteen crew members.
Fate.
"UC-7" sailed from Zeebrugge on 3 July 1916 to lay mines off the English coast and failed to return. sighted a submarine believed to be "UC-7" on 5 July, west of the Bligh Bank, from <a href="Ostend">Ostend</a>. The submarine in question was reported to be on a course that would run it into a minefield, and Verschollen notes that the time and place would be correct if "UC-7" were returning to base. The bodies of two crew members were later washed ashore on the coast of Flanders on 19 July. She was claimed that "UC-7" was sunk by <a href="HMS%20Salmon%20%28H58%29">HMS "Salmon"</a> on 7 July off <a href="Southwold">Southwold</a>, but this was doubted since the reported position was too far off "UC-7"'s operating area.
